s.text: Candida vaginitis [ 3 15 16 17 18 34 ] . While asymptomatic infection is not equivalent to disease, antibiotic use may act to alter the vaginal microenvironment to facilitate Candida colonization in the same way it is hypothesized to promote VVC.
The study population is in no way representative of all females with diabetes, although the age and racial distribution of participants reflected that of the participating clinics.
Potential participants were approached in the clinic waiting room and consent obtained.
These data suggest that behavioral factors, as well as HbA 1c , are important determinants of Candida colonization among women with diabetes.

We found strong, statistically significant associations between vaginal Candida colonization and antibiotic use, lifetime history of chlamydia, diabetes type and HbA 1c level and a borderline significant association with performing oral sex.

After adjustment, older age, having type 1 diabetes, an abnormal HbA 1c level, and report of antibiotic use during the previous 2 weeks were statistically significantly associated with Candida colonization.

Similar to previous reports, C. albicans was isolated from the majority of colonized type 1 participants, while C. glabrata was the most common isolate in type 2 participants, but our numbers are small [ 1 ] . Whether this is due to diabetes type or reflects different distributions of Candida species by age or both is uncertain.

Suspected mixed samples, as determined by colony type and microscopic characteristics, were placed on plates with media showing species-specific colony color change (Chromagar, CHROMagar, Paris, France).

The association we observed with chlamydia is probably a marker of sexual behavior rather than a causal factor; for example, women who reported a history of chlamydia were more likely to douche and to report engaging in oral sex, although it is possible that chlamydia carriage adversely affects the vaginal flora increasing the chance of Candida colonization.

The association we observed with chlamydia is probably a marker of sexual behavior rather than a causal factor; for example, women who reported a history of chlamydia were more likely to douche and to report engaging in oral sex, although it is possible that chlamydia carriage adversely affects the vaginal flora increasing the chance of Candida colonization.

The association we observed with chlamydia is probably a marker of sexual behavior rather than a causal factor; for example, women who reported a history of chlamydia were more likely to douche and to report engaging in oral sex, although it is possible that chlamydia carriage adversely affects the vaginal flora increasing the chance of Candida colonization.
Patients were diagnosed with type 1 and type 2 diabetes on clinical presentation by a board certified endocrinologist.
